section.name: General Settings
section.description: This contains general format settings for UsfmTex macro package.

setting.name: Measurement Unit
setting.description: The unit of measurement used in this publication.

setting.name: Source Encoding Transform
setting.description: In the case of multi-script projects or non-Unicode, an encoding transformation may be needed make the source data useful to the system. The encoding information is stored in the Encoding section and should be the same as other files used in this project. (Default = False)

section.name: Chapter and Verse
section.description: Parameters that cover varous aspects of formating of chapter and verse layout

setting.name: Omit Chapter Number On Single Chapter Book
setting.description: Setting this to True will prevent the chapter number 1 from being displayed single chapter books. Default = True

setting.name: Omit Verse Number One
setting.description: Setting this to True will prevent verse number 1 from being displayed which is normally good for in-line verse formated Bibles that use drop chapter numbers. Default = True

setting.name: Omit All Chapter Numbers
setting.description: Omit all the chapter numbers in the book. (Often this is used for one-chapter books.) Default = False

setting.name: Chapter Verse Separator
setting.description: Change the default c/v separator character or adjust the space by adding some extra code. For example, to kern the space between the separator character you could enter: "\kern.02em:\kern.02em". This setting primary affects the header reference. Default = ":"

setting.name: USFM TeX Marginal Verses
setting.description: To use marginal verses, where the verse numbers are located in the margin, otherwise known as flying verse numbers, set this to True. Default = False

setting.name: USFM TeX After Verse Space Factor
setting.description: You may need a little extra space following the verse numbers. This will add space in this context with a factore that is related to the \FontSizeUnit, this way it scales with the text. This can be used with both in-line and marginal verse layouts. Default = 2

setting.name: USFM TeX After Chapter Space Factor
setting.description: You may need a little extra space following the Chapter numbers. This will add space in this context with a factore that is related to the \FontSizeUnit, this way it scales with the text. This can be used with both in-line and marginal verse layouts. Default = 3

setting.name: USFM TeX Adorn Verse Number Setting
setting.description: By placing a properly formated setting in this field, TeX will place a verse adornment like parenthesis or anything else you may want to specify. An example for parenthesis would be '(#1)' whereas the #1 is the verse number variable. That must be there for the verse number to appear. If you leave it blank no settings will be output to the settings file. Default = nothing
setting.note: Not fully tested yet. More work needs to be done on it.

section.name: Columns
section.description: Parameters which have to do with column layout for Scripture publications

setting.name: Title Columns
setting.description: Number of columns used to typeset the main title. Default = 1

setting.name: Intro Columns
setting.description: Number of columns used to typeset introduction material. Introduction material is defined by USFM markers beginning with \i Default = 1

setting.name: Body Columns
setting.description: Number of columns used to typeset the body text. Default = 1

setting.name: Column Gutter Rule
setting.description: Do you want to place a vertical line between the columns in the column gutter? Default = False

setting.name: USFM TeX Column Gutter Factor
setting.description: Used to set the size of the gutter between columns; this is relative to the font size. Default = 15

setting.name: USFM TeX Column Shift
setting.description: Column shift will shift the colum over n units. This is useful for marginal verse format but there might be other situations where you may need it. Use this if more than one column is being used. It will output both the \columnshift command in the TeX settings file. Only enter the number of millimeters, do not add "mm" as That will be added by the system. Default = 0

setting.name: USFM TeX Column Shift
setting.description: Single column shift will shift a colum over n units. This is useful for marginal verse format but there might be other situations where you may need it. It will output the \singlecolumnshift command in the TeX settings file. Only enter the number of millimeters, do not add "mm" as That will be added by the system. Default = 0

setting.name: USFM TeX Column Gutter Rule Skip
setting.description: It may be necessary to push the top of the gutter rule down a few mm. By setting the number to be greater than zero this will enable you to adjust where the line begins at the top of the page. (Not included in standard ptx2pdf macros). Only enter the number of points, do not add "mm" as That will be added by the system. Default = 0

section.name: Crossreferences
section.description: This section includes all textual elements that go into the Crossreferences area.

setting.name: Include Crossreferences
setting.description: [NOT IMPLEMENTED] Include crossreferences in the output. Defalt = True

setting.name: Use Auto Callers (Crossrefs)
setting.description: Set to true if a symbol or a csv sequence of symbols is needed for crossreferences. Default = True

setting.name: USFM TeX Crossreference Auto Caller Character
setting.description: Define a character or sequence in this field to enable the use of auto callers in your text. You can even add kerning control as well as in the examples By setting something in this field you will override the autoCallerStartChar setting. A sequence = *,+,¶,§,**,++,¶¶,§§ Use only an asterisk = * Kern an asterisk = \kern0.2em*\kern0.4em Raise an asterisk = \raise .8em\hbox{*} Raise and kern = \raise .8em\hbox{\kern0.2em*} Default = *

setting.name: Auto Callers (Crossrefs)
setting.description: Provide a symbol (or a csv sequence of symbols) is desired for a crossref caller character, rather than the default incremental character(s). Default = \kern0.2em *\kern0.4em

setting.name: Numeric Callers (Crossrefs)
setting.description: Use numeric callers on cross references instead of alphabetic callers. Default = False

setting.name: Page Reset Callers (Crossrefs)
setting.description: Restart numbering or character sequence for cross references on each page. Default = False

setting.name: Omit Caller In Crossrefs
setting.description: To omit caller characters from the cross references at the bottom of the page. Default = False

setting.name: Paragraphed Crossrefs
setting.description: Output the crossrefs on the bottom of the page in paragraph format rather than one line for each one. Default = True

section.name: Footnotes
section.description: This section includes all textual elements that go into the footnote area.

setting.name: Include Footnotes
setting.description: [NOT IMPLEMENTED] Include footnotes in the output. Defalt = True

setting.name: Use Auto Callers (Footnotes)
setting.description: Set to true if a symbol or a csv sequence of symbols is needed for footnotes. Default = True

setting.name: Auto Caller Start Character
setting.description: Unicode value of first character to use for auto-generated callers. This allows the use of vernacular caller letters. It will start at the number specified and continue until the number of characters are reached specified by AutoCallerNumChars. Default = 97 ('a')

setting.name: Auto Callers (Footnotes)
setting.description: Provide a symbol (or a csv sequence of symbols) is desired for a footnote caller character, rather than the default incremental character(s). Default = \kern0.2em *\kern0.4em

setting.name: Numeric Callers (Footnotes)
setting.description: Use numeric callers on footnote references instead of alphabetic callers. Default = False

setting.name: Page Reset Callers (Footnotes)
setting.description: Restart numbering or character sequence for footnotes on each page. Default = False

setting.name: Omit Caller In Footnotes
setting.description: To omit caller characters from the footnotes at the bottom of the page. Default = False

setting.name: Paragraphed Footnotes
setting.description: Output the footnotes on the bottom of the page in paragraph format rather than one line for each one. Default = True

setting.name: USFM TeX Define Footnote Rule
setting.description: Many times a horizontal line is used to separate the main text body from the footnotes. To change the default rule that is generated from the macro, change this setting as necessary. If you do not want a footnote rule, insert a command like \smallskip. This will cause the default horizontal line to not be output. Only a small space will be inserted. The default setting will give you a horizontal line across the text area that is 0.4pt in thickness. Some examples of line definitions would be: \hrule height 0.5pt (slightly thicker moving towards the top of the page) \hrule depth 0.5pt (slightly thicker moving towards the bottom of the page) \hrule height 0.5pt\smallskip (small amount of vertical space before text) \smallskip (no rule will be output) Default = \hrule\smallskip

setting.name: USFM TeX Auto Caller Number Characters
setting.description: Number of caller characters to generate before restarting sequence. Default = 26

section.name: Fonts
section.description: Information for fonts used in the publication project.

setting.name: USFM TeX Font Size Unit
setting.description: Using a value in points (pt), this scales the font size of all elements according to the amount of the value. 1pt is equal to 100%. Example, to decrease the size by 5%, enter the value .095pt. Default = 1pt

setting.name: USFM TeX Line Spacing Factor
setting.description: Scaling factor used to adjust line spacing (leading), relative to font size Default = 1.1

setting.name: USFM TeX Vertical Space Factor
setting.description: Scaling factor used to adjust amount of vertical spaces applied for USFM style sheet SpaceBefore and SpaceAfter values. Default = 0.2

setting.name: Use Running Header Rule
setting.description: If this is set to true a rule will be placed in the header according to the Running Header Rule Position. Default = False

setting.name: USFM TeX Header Position
setting.description: Relative position of the baseline of the header to the top edge of the paper (not the text area) Default = 0.5mm

setting.name: USFM TeX Running Header Rule Position
setting.description: Position of rule under the running head if used. It is measured from the baseline of the header. This is a simple dimension, not a relative "factor". Default = 4mm

setting.name: USFM TeX Footer Position
setting.description: Position of the baseline of the footer relative to the bottom edge of the paper (not the text area). Default = 0.5mm

section.name: Footer Content
section.description: Footer Configuration, leave them empty if you don't want anything to show up in the footer, like page numbers on the title page. The default is leave them all empty. Normally we do not want to put any content in the footer as it takes up an extra line which addes up to extra pages in a publication. It is more efficient to put information like page numbers in the running header.

setting.name: Use Running Footer
setting.description: Set this to true if you want to have a running footer line in your document. (Defalt = False)

setting.name: USFM TeX Running Footer Title (Left)

Key words that can be used are: (bookname | rangeref | firstref | lastref | pagenumber | empty) Note: not all of the above have been tested in footer content. Your mileage may vary! (ptx2pdf syntax = \RFtitleleft{}) Default = empty

section.name: Header Content
section.description: Information to include in the running header (at top of pages, except first) We set the items to print at left/center/right of odd and even pages separately Possible contents: \bookname = the name of the book as defined in \h \rangeref = Scripture reference of the range of text on the page; \firstref = reference of the first verse on the page) \lastref = reference of the last verse on the page) \pagenumber = the page number \empty = print nothing in this position To follow are each of the individual position.

setting.name: Use Running Header
setting.description: Set this to true if you want to have a running header line in your document. (Defalt = True)

setting.name: USFM TeX Show Verse References (Running Header)
setting.description: Set this to true if you want to include verse numbers in header/footer references, or only chapter numbers. (ptx2pdf syntax = \VerseRefstrue) Default = False (Only chapter numbers)

setting.name: USFM TeX Omit Book Reference (Running Header)
setting.description: Omit the book name in the running header (RH). Default = False

setting.name: USFM TeX Omit Chapter Number (Running Header)
setting.description: Omit the chapter numbers in the running header (RH). Default = False
setting.note: This is not implemented in usfmTex but can be found in the standard ptx2pdf macro package.

setting.name: USFM TeX Running Header Title (Left Side)
setting.description: This will specify what can go in the running header at this specific position. Key words that can be used are: (bookname | rangeref | firstref | lastref | pagenumber | empty) (ptx2pdf syntax = \RHtitleleft{}) Default = empty

setting.name: USFM TeX Figure Placeholders
setting.description: Turn On Figure Placeholders - If set to true ptx2pdf will not output the actual picture graphic, just the space it goes in. This makes processing much faster. Default = True

setting.name: USFM TeX Chapter Verse Seperator
setting.description: A reference can be included with the illustrations and the seperator can be changed with this setting. The default is ":"

setting.name: USFM TeX Captions
setting.description: Add a caption to the illustration. Set as True if you want captions included with illustrations. Default = True

setting.name: USFM TeX Caption Reference
setting.description: Add illustration reference to caption. Set as true if you want a reference added to the caption. Default = True

setting.name: Path To Illustrations
setting.description: This is the path to the project illustrations that TeX will use.
setting.note: WARNING: The use of '/' at the end of the picPath will probably cause problems cross-platform.

section.name: Margins
section.description: Here find ye settings that affect margin settings. Arrg!

setting.name: USFM TeX Base Margin Unit
setting.description: Basic unit for margins changing this will alter them all. Default = 12mm

setting.name: USFM TeX Top Margin Factor
setting.description: Relative size of the top margin based on MarginUnit will relate just to the margins of the body text area, independent of headers and footers. Default = 1.0

setting.name: USFM TeX Bottom Margin Factor
setting.description: Relative size of the bottom margin based on MarginUnit. If undefined, the \TopMarginFactor will be used for both top and bottom margins. You can set this to "0" to disable this setting. Default = 0

setting.name: USFM TeX Side Margin Factor
setting.description: Relative size of side margin based on MarginUnit. This determins the distance between the edge of the page and the body text. Default = 0.7

setting.name: USFM TeX Extra Right Margin
setting.description: For some single column publications it might be necessary to tweak the right margin to get things to line up, especialy when using marginal verses. This setting is in mm. Enter a number (just a number) which represents the distance in mm that you want to pull the right margin in toward the middle of the page. Defalt = 0mm

setting.name: USFM TeX Binding Gutter
setting.description: If the amount is greater than '0' (zero) additional space will be added to the binding gutter. This additional margin on the binding side of the page will enable printing for formats that need more space for binding like with a comb bind or hole punch. Default = 0mm

section.name: Page Layout
section.description: Page layout information. This covers general page layout format options.

setting.name: Page Size ID Code
setting.description: If you are using a common page size please enter the standard code. If a custom size is being used just enter "custom". Default = A5

setting.name: Starting Page Number
setting.description: Sometimes the content should not start with the default page number of '1'. If a number is set in this field, the macro will insert a \pageno command in the control file. Note this is for the main content section only. Individual components in the front and back matter must have the \pageno command inserted manually into their control files. Default = Null (which means no command output, page starts on '1')

setting.name: USFM TeX Page Height
setting.description: This is the height of the page after it has been printed and trimmed to its final size. Default = 210mm (A5)

setting.name: USFM TeX Page Width
setting.description: This is the width of the page after it has been printed and trimmed to its final size. Default = 148mm (A5)

setting.name: USFM TeX Cropmarks
setting.description: If set to true this will place a set of cropmarks to show page trim size. Default = True

setting.name: USFM TeX Page Border
setting.description: Set this to "true" to put a border on every page. The PDF file containing the border is located in the Illustrations folder in the Source area. To change the border, you can replace the file and change the file name in the System-Files section. Default = False

setting.name: USFM TeX Page Border File
setting.description: Page border default file name. If a page border is used this is the default file name. Change as necessary. This file should be kept in the shared illustrations folder and the system will link it to the Process folder. Default = pageborder.pdf

setting.name: USFM TeX End Book No Eject
setting.description: To save space on long publications the next book can start on the same page of the previous one. Default = False

setting.name: USFM TeX Page Border Scale
setting.description: Enter in the scale factor for the page border and TeX will scale the PDF file as needed. If you do not enter anything, no scaling will be applied. Here are some examples: scaled 900 = 90% of original size scaled 1100 = 110% of original size (not tested yet) xscaled 800 yscaled 900 (to scale individual directions) width 140mm height 205mm (to scale to a known size) Default = Null (which equates to 1000 or no scaling)

section.name: Text Elements
section.description: General settings for text level elements

setting.name: Justify Paragraphs
setting.description: Paragraphs are justified by default. Set this to false to turn off justification. Default = True

setting.name: Right To Left
setting.description: Uncomment to use right-to-left text layout mode Default = False

setting.name: USFM TeX Quote Kern Amount (Em)
setting.description: Often, when there are quotes within quotes, when they end the two types of quote markers are so close together that, from the reader's perspective, it is hard to tell what is going on. To fix this kerning space is added between the two characters to make it clear which is which. The amount is in em space measurement. For more information on what that is, go to this address: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Em_(typography) Enter the amount in em but do not follow with "em" as the system assumes the measurement is in em. Enter 0 if no kerning of quotes is desired. Defalt = 0.1

section.name: TeX Behavior
section.description: Settings that make TeX behave better

setting.name: Horizontal Fuzz
setting.description: Specify the amount that a horizontal box (hbox) can exceed its natrual size before TeX conciders it to be overfull. The normal Plain TeX default is 0.1pt.

setting.name: Vertical Fuzz
setting.description: Specify the amount that a vertical box (vbox) can exceed its natrual size before TeX conciders it to be overfull. The normal Plain TeX default is 0.1pt.
